III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Upon entering the Wolverine Human Services facilities, the Vassar House staff will
utilize the same security/guard booth that services the various boys programs. The
driveway for the Vassar House building is located to the left, between the Clarence
Fischer Center and the WAVES program (Camp 3).
Upon entering the Vassar House building, a comfortable “family room” can be found on
the left. This room complete with a fireplace, is designed to welcome family members of
the residents or other members of the community and provide a relaxed space for
meetings and visits. Across the hallway, to the right of the entrance, will be an open
administrative area. This will house the secretarial staff, clinical staff and locked file
rooms. Further down this hallway on the right, one will find two intake offices designed
to make the transition into residential placement as smooth as possible.
At the end of this hallway, a look to the right will find the self-supported medical
facilities. This area, with its own locked entrance doors, will service Vassar House
youths in a variety of ways. Offices in this area will be held by dental personnel, medical
staff, locked medication storage, and locked medical record storage.
At the end of the first hallway, a left turn will lead to the remaining parts of the building.
On the right-hand side, one will find a large professional kitchen, attached to a dining
commons area that will serve as a multi-purpose room during off-meal times. Looking
into the dining commons are two-way mirrors, allowing staff to observe the safety of the
residents without distracting them or interfering with their activities. These mirrors can
also be found on the opposite side of the hallway, looking into the building’s four
classrooms. There are doors at both ends of these classrooms, providing a congestion-
free way to move one group into a classroom, while moving another group to the next
activity.
A little further down this hallway, across from the remaining classrooms are school
offices and a section of offices and treatment rooms that will house the Growthworks,
Inc. staffing team. These therapists will be the main influence on the youth during their
progression in the “treatment” units, providing top-of-the-line substance abuse therapy.
Through the doors at the end of this hallway, one will find an outdoor covered walkway
that leads directly to the 5 units that will physically house the young women during their
stay at Vassar House. The first two doors on the right will be considered the
“behavioral/stabilization” units, housing 14 young women each during their first few
weeks at the Vassar House program. These units are designed to introduce the young
women to the program and prepare them for their intensive treatment. One of the
3

unique features of these first two units are the “reflection rooms” located next to the
group leader’s office in each unit. These rooms provide a safe environment for young
women to remove themselves from a situation, regain their composure, and return to
the group safely, avoiding any potential conflict or crisis.
After their stay in one of the first two units, the young women will physically move into
the “treatment” units, the third and fourth doors in the row of units. In these units the
young women will receive approximately 90 days of intensive treatment from
Growthworks, Inc. therapists and staff.
Once the young women prove successful in their treatment, they will again make a
move to enter the “reintegration” unit. This final step of the Vassar House program is
located in the larger 12-bed unit on the far left. This unit houses its own kitchen and
laundry facilities and is designed to provide young women with the skills needed to be
successful when they move back into the community. Here they will firm up their
aftercare plans and receive resources that will work to enhance their success and prove
to themselves and the community that they are committed to change.
B. Program Description
Wolverine Human Services, has created a residential behavioral health program,
W-CARE-GI, for adolescent girls, offering chemical dependency education and trauma
informed services. Clients will initially be stabilized behaviorally while being prepared for
an intensive treatment setting. Clinical care will provide a holistic approach, utilizing a
personal recovery plan where girls learn about the relationship between substance use
and traumatic experiences. Girls will gain the ability to regulate intense emotional
responses, often a reaction to traumatic life events, while also developing tools to
remain sober.
An additional component includes a step-down stage which allows the clients to practice
recovery and empowerment tools and prepare for the transition from residential care to
the community. Vocational and life skill development will also be incorporated to
provide each girl with increased chances for successful community reintegration.
Intensive therapy for the program is provided by Growth Works Inc., a leader in the
treatment of chemically depended people.
This facility is fully self-contained and will house up to 70 female clients, ages 12-18. All
intakes will be provided a detailed assessment to determine the appropriate level of
care as defined by ASAM criteria. A multi-dimensional assessment (DUSI-R, youth) also
occurs to guide the treatment planning and individual needs.
As treatment begins, there are four phases that residents can successfully complete.
The first phase is the behavioral stabilization phase. This phase lasts approximately 3-5
weeks and serves to prepare the young woman for treatment expectations. The
behavioral portion is not mandatory and based on a case review can be eliminated.
4

The second phase is the evaluation phase which lasts 5-10 days. The young woman’s
family is brought in for an in-depth intervention concerning the effects of substance
abuse on the family unit.
The primary treatment phase is the third phase and lasts approximately eight weeks.
Residents will identify the impact and consequences of substance use and learn
essential recovery skills. Parents will attend a “Family Week” where they participate in
substance use/abuse education and relationship building to assist in creating a
recovery-supportive home environment.
The step-down phase is the last phase of treatment. This phase begins with a five day
wilderness trek utilizing Wolverine’s Pioneer Adventure Program confidence building
exercises. The young women are reintegrated into their family system via home visits.
After completion of the treatment phases, the young women can enter the transitional
living segment of the Vassar House program. This vitally important phase is designed to
cement after care goals and commitment to sobriety. Community resources will be
developed with a focus on AA/NA meetings and counseling services.
Educational services are provided by the Vassar School System and the Tuscola
County Intermediate School district. There is on-site regular education, as well as
special education services, educational testing and GED testing.
W-CARE-GI treatment modalities will incorporate the Twelve Steps of Recovery from
AA, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, and Motivational Interviewing. These two evidenced
based treatment modalities will be used in conjunction with Wolverine Human Services
Seven Principles (Reality, Responsibility, Respect, Communication, Negotiation,
Education, and Love) as well as the Motivation and Learning System of a point-level
progress structure will be utilized to teach discipline, self-confidence and self-control.
Vassar House is unique in that it concentrates on gender specific issues as well as
treatment. Vassar House treatment staff will provide mentoring relationships rooted in
the realities of girls’ own lives. Vassar House will also provide empowerment strategies
that will assist in building self-esteem and confidence with-in every young woman.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility is in compliance with all rule areas that can be evaluated prior to actual
program implementation, and demonstrates evidence of intent to comply with all
other applicable rule areas.
